article.title: DEVELOPMENT OF OTOLITH RECEPTORS IN JAPANESE QUAIL
article.abstract: The present study examined the morphological development of the otolith vestibular receptors in quail. Here we describe epithelial growth, hair cell density, stereocilia polarization, and afferent nerve innervation during development.

sections.introduction: The vestibular otolith receptors have evolved to detect linear motion and head position with respect to gravity. These are essential functions, about which all coordinated and reflexive movements, as well as spatial orientation and navigation through space depend.
sections.methods: All experiments were conducted in Japanese quail (Coturnix japonica). Otolith organ tissues were collected and analyzed at ten time points during embryonic development (E6-15; hatch on day 16), as well as at three post-hatch (P) developmental times including P1, P7 and adult (8 weeks post-hatch).
sections.results: The total areas of the utricular and saccular receptor epithelia were measured (n = 3 - 16 maculae) for each developmental day from E6â€“E15, P0 (hatch), and for post-hatch days P1 (24 hours post-hatch), P7, and P48 (adult).
sections.discussion: Our findings represent a comprehensive study of the development of the vestibular otolith receptors in birds. We addressed three primary questions.

article.insights_summary: This study examined the development of otolith receptors in Japanese quail, focusing on epithelial growth, hair cell density, stereocilia polarization, and afferent nerve innervation. The results provide a comprehensive understanding of the development of the vestibular otolith receptors in birds.
article.acknowledgments: The authors would like to thank Mark Warchol for valuable discussions.
